title: One Patient with Two Audiological Examinations
chief_complaint: I have 'sensitive hearing' and certain sounds like chewing or coins banging together are painful to me. I also have trouble hearing on my left side and have difficulty understanding speech in background noise.

problem_summary.course: Long-standing; recent onset of dizziness and increased misophonia after stopping medication.
problem_summary.laterality: Left ear hearing loss; bilateral sound sensitivity.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Misophonia (strong negative reaction to soft sounds), recent dizziness, anxiety.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Positions people on her right side to hear; avoids public places without earplugs due to sound sensitivity.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking a second opinion regarding hearing loss and sensitivity; starting a family.

history.present_illness: Patient sought evaluation for hearing loss and sensitivity.
history.otologic_history: Reported history of hearing loss since childhood.
history.prior_management: Diagnosed with asymmetric SNHL; recommended to return to referring physician.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Reported as asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. Right ear shows mild low-frequency loss rising to normal. Left ear shows moderate rising to mild mixed loss (though interpreted as SNHL by previous clinician). Missing bone conduction masking and transducer info.

numeric_results.Right_AC_Thresholds: 25 dB HL at 250 Hz, 20 dB at 500 Hz, improving to 0-10 dB at high frequencies
numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: 40 dB HL at 250 Hz, 35 dB at 500 Hz, rising to 20 dB at 2000 Hz
numeric_results.Left_BC_Unmasked: 10-15 dB HL (indicates air-bone gap, though ignored in previous report)

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs agree with PTAs. Excellent word recognition bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Report text stated 'peaked', but data was not recorded on the form. Acoustic reflexes not recorded.

history.present_illness: Second opinion sought due to communication difficulties and misophonia.
history.otologic_history: No history of ear pathology known to patient. Brother has hearing loss.
history.noise_exposure_history: Does not use hearing protection in public.
history.medical_psych_history: Recently ceased anxiety/OCD medication to start a family.
history.prior_management: Previous hearing aid recommendation mentioned by patient but not pursued.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal hearing (significant improvement from V1). Left ear mild conductive hearing loss with Carhart notch at 2000 Hz. Significant air-bone gaps present in Left ear.

numeric_results.Left_BC_Masked: 0-10 dB HL (normal cochlear function) with notch to 25 dB HL at 2000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with PTAs. Word recognition remains excellent.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanic membrane mobility bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent reflexes bilaterally to ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at 500-4000 Hz (consistent with conductive pathology in the left ear).

tests.name: Weber Tuning Fork
tests.key_findings: Lateralized to the left ear (512 Hz), confirming conductive component.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a mild conductive hearing loss in the left ear. This contrasts with a previous evaluation that suggested bilateral involvement and sensorineural pathology. Current testing reveals a significant air-bone gap in the left ear, a Carhart notch at 2000 Hz, and absent acoustic reflexes, consistent with ossicular chain fixation (otosclerosis).
counseling_points: Your hearing loss in the left ear is 'conductive,' meaning sound is blocked from reaching the inner ear, likely due to a fixation of the tiny bones in your middle ear (otosclerosis).
The previous test results likely had technical errors (masking issues or headphone placement) that made the hearing look worse than it is.
Your inner ear function (nerve hearing) is actually normal in both ears.
Because the loss is conductive, you may be a candidate for medical or surgical management, unlike what you were told previously.
notes_for_actor: Express confusion about why the previous doctor said you had nerve damage but this one might say something different.
Mention that you stopped your anxiety medication because you want to start a family.
